lecturers: ['mr. dr. A.G. Veldman', 'prof. mr. F.J.L. Pennings']
text:
Course goals
After this course:
  • the student has acquired a profound knowledge and understanding of EU social law and policy and its institutional aspects.
  • the student has acquired a profound knowledge and understanding of the areas of freedom of movement of workers and posting, as well as coordination of social security.
  • the student has acquired a profound knowledge and understanding of substantive European labour law in the fields of non-discrimination in the workplace and the restructuring of enterprises.
  • the student has developed skills in legal reasoning and argumentation from the point of view of the plaintiff, defendant or court (moot court)
  • the student has developed presentation/communication skills (in legal English) both written (papers) and orally (presentations).
Content
Since the EU is striving for a ‘social market economy’, it is highly relevant to have a profound insight and understanding of  the social dimension of EU law and policies and the instruments to realize them. After all, the support of the national public for the EU is highly dependent on its social dimension.
We will discuss the institutional aspects of social policy including the powers and competences of the EU in this respect, the available instruments and the particular involvement of the actors in the field (employers and workers)  in standard setting procedures (‘social dialogue’).
The course will subsequently address the free movement of workers and persons, in relation to values and effects for workers and citizens. This part will build on the prior course “Regulating the EU’s Single Market”.  In this context also posting will be dealt with, one of the most controversial topics of the present day EU.  EU Citizenship is a concept that is in particular relevant in relation to social rights, and will be dealt with in this context.
Finally, other major subjects of substantive European labour law will be addressed such as equal treatment in the workplace (on ground of age, part time work and fixed-term contracts))  and the restructuring of enterprises. The latter comprises the EU social regulation to counterbalance economic freedoms in the case of collective dismissals and transfer of undertakings.
 
Place of the course within the curriculum:
  • Elective course in master European Law

college: Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
text:
Course goals 1. Knowledge, understanding, insight
After this course: 
- the student has knowledge and understanding of European substantive law and is able to apply the relevant legislation to complex economic- or societal issues.
- the student understands the core objectives and rules connected to European social regulation and is able to evaluate the desirability of European action on social matters.
- the student understands the core objectives and rules connected to European economic regulation and is able to evaluate the actions of the European Commission in its economic and societal context.
- the student has an insight into the issues that drive- and are connected to the application of European law and is able to make multi-dimensional connections regarding this issue.

2. Contextual positioning
After this course:
- the student is able to place European substantive law in a social context.
- the student can identify the challenges for the European Union from a legal perspective.
- the student can put forward a clear view on European law-related issues.

3. General academic and legal skills
After this course:
- the student is able to systematically analyze case law, decisions and regulations in English, including finding new cases that connect to the subject matter.
- the student has learned how to solve complex legal cases while using the full array of European legal sources, including its translation in national law when necessary.
- the student is able to conduct research and present the outcome in a case note, which makes use of structured and well-informed arguments touching upon multiple viewpoints on the issue concerned.
- the student has gained experience in writing and discussing in English. Content This course teaches European Law from socio-economic perspective on the internal market. This entails that in this course  we will focus on substantive internal market law and its implications for companies and people. The internal market component intertwines with the issue of judicial protection in the EU.  This course will have a clear practical component, in which the students (in the lectures, but even more so in the seminars) will learn what forms and questions of European law they can expect when entering the workforce. Additionally, the course makes use of ‘expert lectures’, that zoom in on a topic relevant to that specific week. In principle, the expert lectures take place every other week.
The structure of the course flows from the foundations of internal market law (free movement rules), through separate people-oriented and business-oriented sections, towards an integrated view on a specific problem. Because of that, 3 weeks of the course will be dedicated to general European law, 2 weeks to social European law, 2 weeks to economic European law and 1 week to a socio-economic problem. The course will be taught in the same form in both period 1 and 3.
In learning about these topics, students will make use of legal texts (Treaties, regulations, directives, case law) and an academic textbook. In addition, some academic articles and news issues relating to current events may be used.
 
Academic context
The course European Law is a mandatory course for the bachelor program Rechtsgeleerdheid. Previous knowledge of the functioning of the EU is therefore required, as this course immediately jumps to the substantive application of European law without focusing on the institutional structure of the EU as such. This knowledge can be gained through the course ‘Inleiding Europees Recht’.
This course seeks to connect the different aspects of European law and incites students to look beyond the ‘borders’ of one problem to see the bigger picture. In doing so, the course often relies on concepts derived from political sciences, governance and economics. The focus of the course is, however, legal in nature.

Societal relevance
The societal context of this course is shaped by the topics of the course, that are geared towards what European law means for people and businesses in practice. This entails that the focus of the course is very much on the application of European law to real-life situations. For certain topics, such as European citizenship (but others are possible as well, depending on the state of the EU), the connection is made with current events and students are incited to look beyond the letter of the law to assess a given situation.
 
Skills
The course European law stimulates and develops the following skills:

Legal skills
The course focuses on applying European law to practical situations. Students are stimulated to apply different legal concepts to cases, to analyze practice from a legal (or multidimensional) perspective and to think of solutions to difficult European law-related problems. This entails that students should, in principle, be able to:
  • Find, use and understand relevant legislation from the European Union and the ECHR.
  • Navigate case law from the Court of Justice and find relevant cases to connect to the subject matter.
  • Analyze practical cases with a view to discussing legal issues and finding solutions.
 
Argumentation and communication
This course demands active participation and a strong presence seminars. This entails that students are expected to put forward their analyses and opinions in a structured way. However, in some seminars emphasis is also put on the process of brainstorming, communicating with group members and forming opinions together. Arguments put forward in class should be cohesive and precise. In working together, students should also be able to correct errors in each other’s reasoning regarding the subject matter. To that end, students have to be able to give each other structured feedback when necessary.

Legal analytical skills
In this course, students are tested (partially) by writing an academic paper on a case or a selected topic of European law. This requires students to evaluate case law or a piece of regulation in a multi-dimensional context. This means that students have to take into account the European perspective, national perspectives and societal context. Attention is paid to information gathering, proper referencing, formulating a research question and a fitting research method.
 

Place of the course within the curriculum:
  • Compulsory legal course
Additional requirements:
Any additional requirements of the course are listed in the "Leidraad" of the course.

college: Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
text:
Course goals
After this course:
 
  • the student has a profound knowledge and understanding of EU law.
  • the student is able to identify relevant legal issues pertaining to EU law in a concrete case.
  • the student is able to do research in EU law and to find relevant legal sources in order to address the legal issues  of the case.
  • the student is able to elaborate a strong argumentation in order to answer the preliminary questions.
  • the student is able to put forward this argumentation in a short written submission.
  • the student is able to present the case in public and defend one point of view.
  • the student can identify diverging and contrasting academic views on an issue in legislation, case law and literature.
  • the student is able to research and analyze a substantial quantity of legal documents and sources relating to specific topics of EU law.
  • the student is able to assess the legal value of the documents found.
  • the student is able to use this analysis and apply relevant legal sources in order to put forward a particular point of view in written pleadings.
  • the student is able to orally present the outcome of the student’s research in English and/or in French and is able to defend the interests of the parties in a case.
  • the student is able to rebut the arguments of fellow students during the moot court competition.
Content
Do you want to give your CV a unique flavour that can open the doors of the best international law firms?
If yes, then the European Law Moot Court competition (hereafter: ELMC) is for you! The ELMC is aimed at all Master students with sufficient knowledge of European Law, English and some knowledge of French (however this condition is not exclusive). Every year in September, a case involving a fictitious Member State of the European Union and concerning issues of interpretation of EU law is published on the website of the ELMC association http://www.europeanlawmootcourt.eu/. At the end of the case several preliminary questions are referred to the Court of Justice of the European Union. The department of European Law selects a team of five students maximum who wish to participate in the competition. The selection takes place at the beginning of September. The selecting committee consists of professors of the European Law Department (Sybe de Vries and Tony Marguery). The criteria for the selection includes knowledge of EU law, capacity to work in an International environment, capacity to work under very tight deadlines and capacity to work both in English and French.
 
From September until the end of November, the team will analyze the case and answer the questions, in order to submit two written pleadings, one for the applicant and one for the defendant, at the end of November. The team of Utrecht University will compete with more than 80 teams from all over the world. The submissions will be reviewed by professional lawyers and the results will be announced mid-January. Only the best pleadings (only 48 teams in general) are selected to continue to the next stage of the competition: the oral rounds (or regional finals). The selected teams will meet and moot at four different universities across Europe and the United States, in February/March. The four teams who won the regional finals will eventually compete in the ELMC final at the Court of Justice in Luxembourg in April.
This international Moot Court competition is a great opportunity to increase your knowledge of European Union Law and to share your Legal skills with other students. It is a unique chance to meet and compete with students from all over the world!
 
Place of the course within the curriculum:
  • Only for selected students: compulsory course in master European Law instead of the course European Labour Law

college: Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
text:
Content Please note the prerequisites for this course, you are expected to have knowledge of certain courses.

The course “European Union Law” aims to provide insight and knowledge into the basic legal principles, legal institutions and the impact of European Union Law. The principle aim of this course is to help students to achieve a critical and informed understanding of the way in which European Union law operates. It offers a general overview of the core principles of the treaties of the EU, secondary legislation and case law.

The course builds on two themes: institutional law, which provides insight in the actors within the European Union, the decision making processes and judicial protection in the European Union, and substantive law, which will be discussed on the basis of internal market law, and even beyond internal market law, on the basis of European Union citizenship.
The institutional part of the course will analyse some of the constitutional principles which form the base of the European Union and play an important role in the division of competences between the European Union and its Member States. Besides, rules concerning the effects of EU law within the national systems will be discussed.

With regard to the second part of the course, in order to achieve the internal market, the Member States of the European Union have decided to share some competence to regulate the free movement of goods, economic active persons, services and capital. Economic activities in these Member States (and also outside the Union) are therefore considerably affected by the internal market. The purpose of this part of the course is to introduce the most important mechanisms concerning this phenomenon in order to determine to what extent the Member States government remain free to regulate the relation between producers and consumers.
Specific aspects of the institutional law of the EU (relating for example to the protection of fundamental rights in the EU legal order) or internal market (relating for example to the regulation of the energy, environment, telecommunication or banking sectors) may be addressed during weekly seminars for which students will have to write and present an essay. Development in both major themes will be discussed in an economic, political and societal context.
 
The student gains a thorough understanding into questions as: ‘What are the reasons for the historical development of the European Union?’; ‘Who are the important actors in the decision making-process and how do these practices work in practices?’; ‘How does the internal market work and how does it affect political and societal differences within the Member States’ and ‘How can we evaluate internal market regulation?’. The course builds on a multidisciplinary approach (including economic theory, historical context and political philosophy), but provides a primarily legal understanding of the theories and rules governing European Union Legislation.
 
Topics to be dealt with include:
I.EU Institutional Law
-          Introduction: general aspects of EU law, structure of the EU;
-          EU institutions and decision-making processes and legal instruments;
-          Supremacy, direct effect of EU law, reception of EU law and state liability;
-          Judicial protection: how to enforce EU law?
 
II. EU Substantive Law
-         Internal market I: introduction to free movement principles, free movement of goods;
-         Internal market II: free movement of services and persons;
-         Internal market III: European Union citizenship;
-         Internal market IV: the free movement of capital and introduction to competition law.
Synthesis: government regulation and economic and practical reality.
 
Learning objectives
After this course, the student:
  • Has a general overview of the core principles of the European Union legal system;
  • Has knowledge and understanding of EU law, both institutional and substantive;
  • Comprehends the importance of the law of the EU for economics;
  • Is able to perform a small research on a topic related to the course and answer a specific question in this regard;
  • Is able to present arguments and the results of his research in writing;
  • Is able to present orally the outcome of his/her research in English;
  • Is able to lead a discussion in the class on the topic of the essay presented;
  • Has developed a vision on the broader economic, political and societal context of European Union law.
Format
Lectures, tutorials and seminars, including discussion-tutorials and case-questions, presentation of essays during seminars.
 
Assessment method
  • Paper and presentation (20%)
  • Written exam (open questions)(80%)                               
Effort requirements
Attendance to the weekly lecture is not compulsory. By contrast, students are obliged to attend 80% of the weekly tutorials and seminars, and should participate actively in class discussions. In order to do so, students are expected to study in detail the mandatory literature for each week in advance. It is expected that students bring their text of the Treaty with them to each seminar and tutorial. For each seminar the answers to the seminar questions of several students will be randomly collected for review (however, no grade will be given by the teacher, only feedback).
Besides, the students will have to write a small essay (1000 to 1500 words) on one of the topics discussed in class. This assignment implies also that students do some research on their own in specific fields of EU law. The purpose of the essay is to focus on one question, a thesis, and use the essay to answer the question. Students will present these essays during weekly seminars.
 
Language of instruction
English
 
Place of the course within the curriculum
The course is part of the Law Minor of U.S.E. The course is only open to U.S.E. students. Students must have followed the course Introduction to Law (ECB1IL) in order to apply for this course.

Course goals
After completing this course students are able to:
  • demonstrate knowledge of the specific characteristics of European law.
  • apply basic skills of research, analysis, and argumentation to questions of European law. 
Content
Since the impact of European law on the daily lives of citizens has increased, knowledge of this field has become important for practitioners engaged in a wide range of professional activities. This course provides students with the necessary knowledge and skills to understand the extent of this impact. It begins with a critical overview of the legal system of the European Union: its origin, the evolution of its legal rules, the legal construct of economic freedoms, and European integration.
Subjects include: the Internal Market and European competition law, the legal foundations of the European Union; the institutions of the European Union and their decision-making competence; the sources of the law of the European Union; the relationship between the legal system of the European Union and those of member States; and the enforcement of European Union law at the European and national level. The sessions on economic law introduce the four freedoms and competition law on which the internal market is based and the way in which these policies are affected through Community law and upheld by the European Court of Justice.

Format
The first part of the course is structured on the basis of a lecture/seminar set up. The instructor introduces main issues each week in an interactive lecture, whereas seminars are meant to further discuss legal issues more in-depth on the basis of seminar questions and cases. This part of the course is concluded by an exam in the first week of November.
During the second part of the course, each student is part of two small groups (3-4 students). The first group is the research clinic group. Each group is assigned a researcher studying a particular EU related issue. The group then acts as host for their researcher-of-the-day, presents the research and leads the class discussion. The second group each student is part of is the moot court group. Students participate in a moot court simulation that consists of a written and an oral part.

college: Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
text:
Course goals After this course:
  • the student has knowledge of the most important aspects of the European integration and internationalizing of criminal law.
  • the student has knowledge of the international cooperation on criminal matters.
  • the student is able to analyze and apply national criminal law in light of European integration.
 
Content
This course will give an overview of the most important aspects of the European integration and internationalizing of criminal law. An other important part of this course will deal with international cooperation in criminal matters.
Attention will be given to some topics as: International criminal law, jurisdiction, Conventions of the Council of Europe, enforcement mechanism of the institutions within the EU, transnational cooperation, European judicial area, mutual recognition/harmonisation, Extradition/European Arrest Warrant, Eurojust, Europol, European Public prosecutor, European Convention.

Place of the course in the curriculum:
  • Compulsory course in the specialisation "European Criminal Law and Human Rights'

college: Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
text:
Course goals

After completing this course students have:
  • knowledge and understanding of European politics, and decision-making procedures at different decision-making levels;
  • knowledge and understanding of different theoretical perspectives on European decision-making and influence on policy;
  • understanding of practices of European governance by means of different specific cases;
  • practical applications of the readings on a selected case of European lobbying. 
Content
Ever since its origin, the European Union aimed to solve cross-border problems, and to avoid military conflict between states. With the widening of the Union from safety and economic issues to environmental, legal and social issues in the 1980s, the impact of the EU has increased dramatically. Increasingly, the EU determines the room for maneuver of the Dutch administration, Dutch business entrepreneurs and civil society. For example, the EU plays an increasingly important role in issues such as migration, health care and the financial crisis. However, the EU also has an increasingly strong impact on the lives of ordinary citizens. We pay in euros, study to become Bachelors or Masters, and are confronted with traffic policies that are directly inspired by the European environmental directives.
This course aims to give more insight into the making of European policies and its consequences for its citizens. The course will therefore use both a bottom-up and a top-down perspective, and focus on the forces that speed up or slow down European integration, the formal and informal procedures by which European policy is made, and the effects of European decision-making for politics, society and citizens. The course will use theoretical perspectives from public administration and political science. The knowledge gained from these insights will be assessed by means of a written exam.
In addition, you will work intensively on a number of recent cases of European governance to gain more understanding in its actual processes. Special attention will be paid to (amongst other things):
  • Brexit;
  • the role of the EU in the financial crisis;
  • the role of the EU in the refugee crisis;
  • euroscepsis;
  • enlargement of the EU (Turkey) and its consequences;
  • what are the formal and informal venues for lobbying? What is the most effective strategy to influence decision-making on this issue?
  • theoretical and practical insights will come together in a paper that you write on a case of lobbying in Europe; a case selected by yourself by either a civil society actor or governmental actor. Questions addressed in the paper include: how does EU decision-making work in this issue-area?
Please note that for non-USG bachelor students the course Introduction public administration and organizational science (USG5520/USG5020) or another introductional course covering the subject of public administration is recommended.
